supporting_sources.title: Tracking COVID-19 with wastewater | Nature Biotechnology
supporting_sources.content: The article from Nature Biotechnology, published on September 21, 2020, discusses the potential of using wastewater surveillance to track the spread of COVID-19, offering a complementary method to traditional epidemiological indicators. Researchers, including David A. Larsen and Krista R. Wigginton, highlight the limitations of current COVID-19 tracking methods, such as diagnostic testing and hospitalization data, which can be biased and delayed. The study by Peccia et al. in New Haven, Connecticut, demonstrated that concentrations of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in sewage sludge correlated with COVID-19 cases and hospital admissions, suggesting that wastewater data could provide near-real-time insights into community transmission. This method, which has been effective in monitoring other viral diseases like polio, is cost-effective and less invasive, capturing data from individuals who may not have access to healthcare. The study found that SARS-CoV-2 RNA concentrations in sludge ranged from 1.7 × 10³ to 4.6 × 10⁵ copies per milliliter, and the data provided early warning of epidemiological trends when accounting for delays in diagnostic testing. Despite challenges in directly correlating viral RNA concentrations to disease prevalence due to biological and infrastructural variability, wastewater surveillance could enhance public health responses, especially in areas with testing delays. The article calls for further research to refine this approach and integrate it into a broader surveillance network, potentially aiding in the timely deployment of interventions and vaccines.

supporting_sources.title: Presence of SARS-Coronavirus-2 in sewage - medRxiv
supporting_sources.content: The study investigates the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in sewage during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, highlighting its potential as a surveillance tool. Researchers collected sewage samples from wastewater treatment plants (WWTP) in seven cities and an airport, testing them using RT-PCR for fragments of the virus's nucleocapsid and envelope protein genes. Initial samples from February 6, 2020, showed no virus presence, but by March 5, the N1 fragment was detected in five sites, and by March 15/16, N1 was found in six sites, with N3 and E fragments detected in five and four sites, respectively. This detection aligns with the emergence of COVID-19 cases in the Netherlands, suggesting that sewage surveillance could sensitively monitor virus circulation, even at low prevalence levels. The study emphasizes the importance of sewage surveillance as a complementary tool to clinical surveillance, potentially serving as an early warning system for COVID-19 outbreaks. The research was supported by KWR Water Research Institute and involved collaboration with local water authorities and WWTP operators.

supporting_sources.title: Presence of SARS-Coronavirus-2 in sewage - medRxiv
supporting_sources.content: The study investigates the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in sewage during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, highlighting its potential as a surveillance tool. Researchers collected sewage samples from seven cities and an airport, analyzing them using RT-PCR to detect fragments of the nucleocapsid protein gene (N1-3) and the envelope protein gene (E). Initially, no SARS-CoV-2 was found in samples from February 6, prior to the first reported case in the country on February 27. However, by March 5, the N1 fragment was detected in sewage from five sites, and by March 15/16, the N1 fragment was found in six sites, with the N3 and E fragments detected in five and four sites, respectively. This marks the first report of SARS-CoV-2 detection in sewage, suggesting that sewage surveillance could effectively monitor virus circulation even at low prevalence levels. The research was funded by KWR Water Research Institute, with no external funding, and adhered to all ethical guidelines and reporting standards.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus: occurrence, surveillance, and persistence in wastewater
supporting_sources.content: The article "Coronavirus: occurrence, surveillance, and persistence in wastewater," published in Environmental Monitoring and Assessment, explores the role of wastewater in monitoring the spread of COVID-19. The study highlights the importance of understanding the behavior of the coronavirus in the environment to develop effective control measures. It discusses the detection of low concentrations of coronavirus and its nucleic acids in municipal wastewater, which can serve as an early warning system for outbreaks and help identify asymptomatic carriers. The review focuses on four key areas: the occurrence of coronavirus in wastewater, wastewater-based epidemiological surveillance, tools for detecting coronaviruses in sewage, and the persistence of coronaviruses in wastewater. Various methods, including RT-qPCR and metagenomics, are used to detect viral RNA in wastewater, providing insights into the prevalence and spread of the virus in communities. The study emphasizes the potential of wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) as a tool for early detection and monitoring of COVID-19 and other viral outbreaks, highlighting its cost-effectiveness and ability to provide real-time data on community health. The persistence of coronaviruses in wastewater is influenced by factors such as temperature and organic matter, with the virus showing rapid inactivation in these environments. The article concludes that while coronaviruses are not a major problem for water industries due to their low concentrations and susceptibility to degradation, their presence in wastewater can serve as a valuable biomarker for epidemiological surveillance.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak: some serious
supporting_sources.content: The article published in npj Clean Water on July 3, 2020, explores the potential consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic on urban and rural water cycles, particularly focusing on the risk of transmission through water contaminated with SARS-CoV-2. The study highlights the virus's high transmission rate and the lack of treatment options at the time, emphasizing the possibility of faecal-oral transmission. It notes that while conventional sewage treatment methods with disinfection can eradicate the virus, densely populated countries like India, with limited sewage treatment facilities, face a high risk of contamination. The virus can survive for several days in untreated sewage, posing a significant threat to the 1.8 billion people worldwide who use faecal-contaminated water sources. The study underscores the importance of preventing water pollution at collection, distribution, and consumption points and implementing WHO recommendations for plumbing and ventilation systems to curb the spread of COVID-19. It also discusses the potential for wastewater-based epidemiology as an early warning system and the need for proper wastewater treatment to prevent community transmission. The article concludes that while conventional tertiary wastewater treatment systems are expected to be effective, the high percentage of untreated sewage in countries like India necessitates stringent measures to prevent water contamination and control the outbreak.

supporting_sources.title: Sewage could provide early warning of COVID-19 outbreaks
supporting_sources.content: The article from Medical News Today discusses the potential of using wastewater to provide early warnings of COVID-19 outbreaks. This approach, known as wastewater-based epidemiology, has been proposed by scientists in the U.K. and China after the SARS-CoV-2 virus was detected in stool samples of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in the U.S. Wastewater analysis is already used in the U.S. and Europe to monitor illicit drug use and other health indicators. Dr. Zhugen Yang and his team at Cranfield University and the Chinese Academy of Sciences have developed a paper-based test that could detect the virus in wastewater, offering a cost-effective and rapid alternative to traditional lab tests. This test, which builds on Yang's previous work on malaria detection, could be crucial for identifying asymptomatic carriers and implementing early quarantine measures. The paper device, which costs less than 50 cents, uses origami-like folds to process samples and can deliver results in about 50 minutes. It is compact, easy to use, and can be safely disposed of by incineration. The development of this test is supported by the Natural Environment Research Council and the Royal Academy of Engineering in the U.K., with an estimated timeline of up to a year for full development and validation.

supporting_sources.title: Evidence suggests COVID-19 is not transmitted through wastewater
supporting_sources.content: The report by Dr. Mark Sobsey from the UNC Gillings School of Global Public Health addresses concerns about the potential transmission of COVID-19 through wastewater. Despite the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater, which indicates community spread, Sobsey's review, published in the Journal of Water & Health, finds no evidence that the virus in fecal waste is infectious or capable of spreading. The virus is primarily transmitted through aerosols and respiratory droplets, and while infected individuals shed viral particles in fecal waste, Sobsey's analysis of scientific literature and studies shows no documented cases of COVID-19 transmission through water or wastewater. As a retired Kenan Distinguished Professor and advisor for WHO and CDC, Sobsey's expertise has been crucial in guiding public health experts on the risks of COVID-19 exposure through water. His findings emphasize that there is no epidemiological evidence linking water and wastewater to human cases or outbreaks of COVID-19, thus negating the need for concern over transmission through these sources.

supporting_sources.title: Scientists Have a New Tool for Tracking COVID-19 Variants - Time
supporting_sources.content: The article by Alice Park discusses a novel approach developed by scientists for tracking COVID-19 variants through wastewater analysis, providing a more comprehensive and early detection method compared to traditional testing. During the pandemic, wastewater has been a valuable tool for identifying peaks in infections before they are evident in healthcare settings. Researchers, led by Rob Knight at the University of California, San Diego, have enhanced this method to not only detect the presence of SARS-CoV-2 but also identify specific variants by analyzing genetic signatures in wastewater samples. This approach was tested on nearly 20,000 samples from the UC San Diego campus, allowing the team to detect infection trends up to 14 days before they were confirmed by clinical tests. The system also enabled the identification of a broader range of virus strains than those detected through PCR tests, offering a more accurate picture of variant diversity. The study, which collected data from November 2020 to February 2022, successfully tracked the emergence and prevalence of variants like Alpha, Delta, and Omicron, demonstrating the rapid replacement of Delta by Omicron. The findings underscore the potential of wastewater surveillance as an unbiased, community-wide indicator of infection dynamics, offering public health officials a powerful tool to anticipate and respond to outbreaks. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recognized this potential, launching a National Wastewater Surveillance Program to monitor virus loads across the country. This method addresses biases inherent in clinical testing and provides a leading indicator of infection trends, crucial for managing the ongoing evolution of SARS-CoV-2.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Monitoring in Maricopa County
supporting_sources.content: The Maricopa County Department of Public Health (MCDPH) plays a pivotal role in Arizona's wastewater surveillance program, collaborating with the Arizona Department of Health Services (ADHS), city agencies, utilities, and laboratories as part of the National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS) initiated by the CDC in 2020. This program monitors wastewater for pathogens like SARS-CoV-2, influenza A & B, influenza A(H5), and RSV A & B, alongside illicit substances, to enhance public health responses. Wastewater-based epidemiology offers a comprehensive view of community health by analyzing genetic material from pathogens and chemical targets in sewage, providing insights into disease prevalence and substance use without relying on healthcare-seeking behaviors. This method can detect disease spread, such as COVID-19, days before clinical data, offering a proactive approach to public health. However, challenges include data interpretation and comparison across different sewersheds due to variability in sampling methods and community characteristics. In Maricopa County, cities like Phoenix, Tempe, and Surprise participate in this surveillance, with Tempe also monitoring additional pathogens and drugs. The program's data, collected bi-weekly, is crucial for understanding community health trends and informing timely interventions. Despite its benefits, wastewater monitoring faces limitations, such as the inability to pinpoint pathogen origins within a community and the complexity of comparing data across regions. Efforts continue to refine these methods to improve accuracy and utility in public health decision-making.

supporting_sources.title: Why sewage may hold the key to tracking diseases far beyond
supporting_sources.content: The article by Betsy Ladyzhets in Science News explores the burgeoning field of wastewater surveillance as a tool for tracking public health threats beyond COVID-19. Initially a niche area focused on detecting drugs and mapping microbial ecosystems, wastewater surveillance gained prominence during the COVID-19 pandemic by successfully tracking the spread of the virus and its variants. This success has led to a rapid expansion of the field, with hundreds of wastewater treatment plants in the U.S. and globally participating in monitoring programs like the National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS). Researchers are now exploring the potential of this method to track a variety of pathogens, including seasonal diseases like the flu, emerging threats like bird flu and mpox, and drug-resistant pathogens such as Candida auris. Despite its promise, the field faces challenges, including the need for standardized protocols and sustained funding, as well as the difficulty of translating environmental data into actionable public health policies. The article highlights the potential of wastewater surveillance to provide early warnings of disease outbreaks, but emphasizes the need for further research and collaboration among scientists, health officials, and policymakers to fully realize its benefits.

supporting_sources.title: New Article in The Conversation: COVID-19 clues in a community's
supporting_sources.content: The article from the University of Notre Dame's GERM Lab, published in The Conversation and authored by Katherine Crank, explores the potential of monitoring community sewage to detect COVID-19. This method, while gaining recent attention, has historical roots dating back to the 1940s when scientists began examining sewage for pathogens like poliovirus. The process involves detecting fragments of the virus's RNA in wastewater, as approximately two-thirds of individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2 excrete the virus in their stool. The approach typically requires concentrating the wastewater sample to enhance the likelihood of detecting viral RNA, which is achieved through techniques like electrostatic interaction to capture the RNA fragments. Although this method provides valuable data, the article notes that it is not yet possible to directly correlate the amount of viral RNA in wastewater to the exact number of infected individuals in a community. This innovative surveillance strategy offers a promising tool for public health monitoring, despite the current limitations in quantifying community infection rates directly from wastewater analysis.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Epidemiology & Surveillance Program | Texas DSHS
supporting_sources.content: The Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) provides an overview of its Wastewater Epidemiology & Surveillance Program, which is part of the Environmental Epidemiology & Disease Registries Section. This program utilizes wastewater surveillance to monitor pathogens within communities, offering a non-invasive, timely, and cost-effective method to track infectious disease trends. Wastewater, which includes household and non-household water, is systematically sampled and analyzed to detect genetic material from pathogens, even from asymptomatic individuals. This approach complements traditional public health tools like clinical testing and has been particularly effective during the COVID-19 pandemic for tracking SARS-CoV-2 levels. The data collected can alert public health officials to disease trends earlier than clinical testing, confirm infection rates, and identify pathogen variants of concern, such as the Omicron variant. DSHS collaborates with local health departments and water utilities to collect and interpret this data, which helps shape public health policies and direct resources to areas with high transmission rates. The program invites municipalities interested in participating to contact them for more information.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus Q&As: Member Questions, Wastewater Surveillance
supporting_sources.content: The article discusses the role of wastewater professionals in monitoring the spread of COVID-19 through wastewater surveillance, as highlighted in a series of webinars sponsored by WEST YOST and organized by CASA-CWEA. The webinars address various questions from members regarding the presence and infectivity of the coronavirus in wastewater. According to the CDC and WEF, there is no evidence of viable COVID-19 virus in wastewater systems, and the virus is unlikely to survive the disinfection processes used in water treatment. The CDC clarifies that while RNA from the virus is detectable in wastewater and feces, this does not indicate infectivity. The article also covers safety recommendations for wastewater workers, emphasizing the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) and hygiene practices to prevent infection. Additionally, the CDC is evaluating the potential of wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) to estimate community infection levels, though widespread monitoring is not currently recommended. The article also touches on the challenges of detecting the virus in wastewater, the potential impact of pre-chlorination, and the need for rapid testing results to inform public health actions. The discussion includes the use of PCR for virus detection, the importance of sample concentration, and the potential for using robots in sample collection. The article concludes with insights into the costs and logistics of wastewater testing, the use of UV light for disinfection, and the testing protocols for wastewater employees.

supporting_sources.title: Califor​nia Wastewater Surveillance Network Dashboard - CDPH
supporting_sources.content: The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) has developed a new Wastewater Surveillance Dashboard to monitor SARS-CoV-2 levels in wastewater across California. This initiative, part of the California Wastewater Surveillance Network (CA WWS Network), involves collaboration between CDPH, wastewater utilities, academic institutions, and laboratories. The dashboard provides a visual representation of SARS-CoV-2 RNA concentrations in wastewater, with data updated daily from Monday to Friday. Wastewater samples are typically collected on Sundays, Mondays, and Wednesdays, with a turnaround time of 3-6 days for results to appear on the dashboard. The data is presented as either raw or normalized concentrations, with normalization using the Pepper Mild Mottle virus (PMMoV) as a human fecal indicator, which has shown improved correlation with COVID-19 case incidence rates. The dashboard includes maps of sewersheds, showing where samples are collected, and graphs displaying average concentrations and 10-day rolling averages to highlight trends. The CDPH emphasizes that wastewater surveillance is an evolving field, and the data should be interpreted with caution. The full dataset is available on the California Open Data Portal, and further inquiries can be directed to the CDPH Cal-SuWers Team.

supporting_sources.title: An interpretative review of the wastewater-based surveillance of the
supporting_sources.content: The article from Frontiers in Microbiology provides an in-depth review of wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) as a tool for monitoring the presence and spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. Historically used since the 1940s for tracking diseases like polio and hepatitis, WBE has gained prominence for its potential in early detection of SARS-CoV-2 at the community level. The review compiles data from 68 studies across 26 countries, highlighting various methods for detecting the virus in wastewater, including serological, biosensor, PCR, and next-generation sequencing techniques. The presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in wastewater, which results from viral shedding in human feces, saliva, and other secretions, can serve as an early warning system, potentially identifying outbreaks before clinical cases are reported. The article emphasizes the need for continued development of sensitive, cost-effective surveillance strategies, especially in light of emerging variants like JN.1. Despite the promise of WBE, challenges remain, such as correlating viral load in wastewater with actual infection rates and understanding the virus's viability in these environments. The review underscores the importance of WBE in public health planning and pandemic preparedness, advocating for its integration into long-term surveillance strategies to mitigate the impacts of current and future viral outbreaks.

supporting_sources.title: Waste water flowing in communities can reveal presence of COVID-19
supporting_sources.content: The article from Healthwise by Punch Nigeria Limited covers a range of health-related topics, highlighting significant issues and developments. It begins with the Guild of Medical Directors criticizing the imposition of parking fees on private hospitals in Lagos, arguing that it adds unnecessary financial burdens. In another report, experts advocate for data-driven strategies to address maternal mortality and stillbirths in Nigeria, emphasizing the importance of accurate data in formulating effective health policies. The Medical Laboratory Science Council of Nigeria recently inducted 45 graduates from the University of Lagos, marking a significant step in bolstering the country's healthcare workforce. Meanwhile, a severe Lassa fever outbreak in Nigeria has resulted in 80 deaths within a week, prompting calls for improved hygiene practices to curb the spread. Additionally, experts in sexual health reassure that penis size does not significantly impact sexual performance or fertility. In a separate study, scientists are exploring wastewater analysis as a method to detect COVID-19 presence in communities, offering a non-invasive early-warning system for potential outbreaks. This approach, already yielding results in countries like the Netherlands, the U.S., and Sweden, could provide a more comprehensive understanding of virus spread than individual testing, as it accounts for asymptomatic cases.

supporting_sources.title: MDE COVID-19 Update - Maryland Department of the Environment
supporting_sources.content: The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) provides an update on various initiatives and regulatory adjustments in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The department highlights the Sewer Sentinel Initiative and the availability of related maps, as well as the careful exercise of enforcement discretion during this period. A significant focus is on the status of water, wastewater, and industrial wastewater operator certifications. Under the Governor's Executive Order, certifications that expired on or after April 1, 2020, have been administratively renewed and remain active until June 30, 2021, with late fees resuming on July 1, 2021. Certifications that expired between January 1, 2020, and March 1, 2020, were within a 90-day grace period and are now considered inactive, with reinstatement resuming on July 1, 2021. Certifications that expired before December 31, 2019, are inactive, and those beyond the two-year reinstatement period cannot be renewed. The MDE also provides guidance on electronically accepted permit applications and Public Information Act requests, directing inquiries to the Board of Waterworks and Waste Systems Operators via email. The department maintains communication through various social media channels.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Testing - Mathematica
supporting_sources.content: The article from Mathematica highlights the organization's multifaceted approach to leveraging data and evidence-based strategies to address public health challenges, with a particular focus on wastewater testing. Wastewater monitoring is presented as a cost-effective and rapid method for detecting viral particles, chemicals, and pathogens, providing public officials with timely insights into community health trends. This method is especially valuable for tracking COVID-19 infections, offering early warnings of outbreaks and helping to manage public health responses. The article details how Mathematica collaborates with municipalities and community partners to scale these efforts, using statistical analysis and decision support tools to translate lab results into actionable insights. Additionally, the article discusses the application of wastewater data in confronting the opioid epidemic, highlighting its potential in emerging drug detection and overdose prediction. Mathematica's work extends globally, emphasizing the need for coordinated wastewater monitoring practices and addressing the costs associated with such efforts in low- and middle-income countries. The organization also offers a range of services, including enhanced surveillance, policy guidance, and mitigation strategies, to support public health officials in making informed decisions.

supporting_sources.title: Monitoring SARS-CoV-2 variants in wastewater of Dhaka City
supporting_sources.content: The study published in "Human Genomics" on July 7, 2023, investigates the dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 variants in the wastewater of Dhaka City, Bangladesh, as a complementary approach to public health surveillance. Given the challenges of limited wastewater treatment in Dhaka, the study aimed to explore the genetic diversity of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater and its correlation with clinical data. Researchers collected 504 wastewater samples from various sites, including community drains, hospital septic tanks, and pumping stations, between September 2020 and May 2021. Using RT-qPCR, 36.7% of these samples tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA, with a median concentration of 5.2 log10 N gene copies per liter. Whole genome sequencing of selected samples revealed the presence of multiple clades and lineages, including the Delta variant, which was detected in wastewater months before its identification in clinical samples. This finding underscores the potential of wastewater surveillance in early detection and monitoring of SARS-CoV-2 variants, providing valuable insights for public health strategies. The study highlights the importance of environmental surveillance in densely populated areas with inadequate sanitation infrastructure, offering a cost-effective method for tracking viral spread and informing public health responses.

supporting_sources.title: Houston Wastewater Epidemiology
supporting_sources.content: The article details the Houston Wastewater Epidemiology initiative, a collaborative effort between the Houston Health Department, Rice University, and Houston Public Works, aimed at monitoring wastewater to detect pathogens responsible for communicable diseases such as COVID-19, influenza, and RSV. This program involves weekly sampling from various wastewater sites across Houston, with samples analyzed by independent labs to identify the presence of these pathogens. The data serves as an early warning system, allowing health officials to advise the public on preventive measures. A significant component of this initiative is the pilot program launched in December 2020 with the Houston Independent School District, which monitors wastewater from school bathrooms to detect germs. Alerts are sent to the community via text or email when pathogens are detected, providing guidance on protective actions, such as vaccination. The article reassures that Houston's drinking water remains safe, as it is supplied through a separate system. Additionally, it provides information on COVID-19, flu, and RSV, including symptoms, transmission, and preventive measures, emphasizing the importance of vaccination and hygiene practices. The article also offers resources for further information and access to health services, including immunizations and testing.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Covid-19 Tracking - MWRA
supporting_sources.content: The Massachusetts Water Resources Authority (MWRA) is conducting a pilot study at the Deer Island Treatment Plant to track COVID-19 infection indicators through wastewater analysis. This initiative involves daily sample analysis by Biobot Analytics, a company specializing in wastewater epidemiology. Results are typically posted 2-3 working days after collection, with the latest data available up to February 18, 2025. A recent calibration update by Biobot Analytics has slightly adjusted individual data points from the past six months, though overall trends remain unchanged. The data, represented in graphs with error bars indicating variability, is divided into the North and South Systems, marked by green and orange dots, respectively. The study also includes variant screening results and is complemented by additional disease target testing through the WastewaterSCAN program. For further context, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provide additional information on SARS-CoV-2 genetic material in wastewater. The MWRA encourages the public to refer to the Massachusetts Department of Public Health for current COVID-19 case information in their communities.

supporting_sources.title: Isolation and characterization of a bat SARS-like coronavirus that
supporting_sources.content: The article published in Nature on October 30, 2013, details a study on the isolation and characterization of a bat SARS-like coronavirus (SL-CoV) that utilizes the ACE2 receptor, a key entry point for the SARS-CoV virus in humans. The study was conducted in response to the 2002-2003 SARS pandemic and the ongoing threat posed by coronaviruses, such as the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV). Researchers conducted a 12-month survey in Yunnan, China, collecting 117 samples from Chinese horseshoe bats. Using reverse transcription PCR, they identified two novel SL-CoVs, RsSHC014 and Rs3367, which showed a 95% nucleotide sequence identity with human SARS-CoV, significantly higher than previously identified bat SL-CoVs. Notably, they successfully isolated a live virus, SL-CoV-WIV1, from bat fecal samples, which demonstrated the ability to use ACE2 receptors from humans, civets, and bats for cell entry. This finding suggests that Chinese horseshoe bats are natural reservoirs of SARS-CoV and that direct bat-to-human transmission is possible without intermediate hosts. The study underscores the importance of pathogen discovery programs targeting wildlife to predict and prevent potential pandemics.

supporting_sources.title: Bat coronaviruses related to SARS-CoV-2 and infectious for  - Nature
supporting_sources.content: The article published in Nature on February 16, 2022, investigates the origins of SARS-CoV-2 by exploring bat coronaviruses in northern Laos. Researchers conducted a study to identify bat coronaviruses genetically similar to SARS-CoV-2 that can infect human cells. They captured 645 bats from 46 species, collecting various samples for analysis. Using next-generation sequencing and phylogenetic analyses, they identified five sarbecoviruses closely related to SARS-CoV-2. Notably, the receptor-binding domains (RBDs) of these viruses differ from SARS-CoV-2 by only one or two residues, allowing them to bind more efficiently to the human ACE2 receptor than the original Wuhan strain. Despite lacking a furin cleavage site, these viruses can enter and replicate in human cells, suggesting a potential risk for direct transmission to humans. The study highlights the presence of bat-borne SARS-CoV-2-like viruses in the Indochinese peninsula, contributing to understanding the virus's origins and potential future risks.

supporting_sources.title: Bat origin of human coronaviruses | Virology Journal | Full Text
supporting_sources.content: The article published in the Virology Journal on December 22, 2015, explores the bat origin of human coronaviruses, particularly focusing on SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV. Bats are identified as natural reservoirs for a wide variety of viruses, including coronaviruses, which have been linked to significant human disease outbreaks in the 21st century. The study highlights that various species of horseshoe bats in China harbor genetically diverse SARS-like coronaviruses, some of which are highly similar to SARS-CoV and can use the same receptor for cell entry. Similarly, coronaviruses related to MERS-CoV have been found in bats worldwide, with some strains classified within the same species as MERS-CoV. The research underscores the role of intermediate hosts in the transmission of these viruses from bats to humans, emphasizing the importance of understanding these dynamics to predict and prevent future pandemics. The study employs genomic analysis and phylogenetic classification to demonstrate the evolutionary link between bat coronaviruses and human infections, revealing that bats are likely the original hosts of these viruses. The article concludes that ongoing surveillance and research into bat coronaviruses are crucial for public health preparedness against potential zoonotic spillovers.

supporting_sources.title: Bats confirmed host of SARS virus - CSIRO
supporting_sources.content: The article from Australia's National Science Agency details the identification of bats as the natural reservoir for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-like coronaviruses. SARS first emerged in 2002-03 in southern China, causing a global pandemic that resulted in 774 deaths out of 8,094 infections, significantly impacting international travel and trade. In 2005, a collaborative study involving CSIRO scientists and international researchers found that bats are likely the natural hosts of the virus responsible for SARS. This was based on the discovery that certain bat species carry coronaviruses closely related to SARS-CoV, with greater genetic variation than those found in humans or civet cats. In 2013, further research led by Professor Shi Zhengli and CSIRO's Professor Linfa Wang confirmed this by isolating a SARS-like coronavirus, SL-CoV WIV1, from horseshoe bats in China, definitively establishing bats as the origin of the virus. This breakthrough, published in Nature, underscores the importance of protecting bat habitats to prevent them from encroaching on urban areas, thereby reducing the risk of zoonotic disease transmission. The findings are crucial for developing effective prevention strategies against SARS and similar epidemics, highlighting CSIRO's commitment to addressing biosecurity threats through innovative science.

supporting_sources.title: New Sars-like Coronavirus Discovered in Chinese Horseshoe Bats
supporting_sources.content: The article from EcoHealth Alliance, a nonprofit organization focused on conservation and global health, announces the discovery of a new SARS-like coronavirus in Chinese horseshoe bats, a decade after the original SARS outbreak. This discovery, published in the journal Nature, was made by an international team of scientists from China, Australia, Singapore, and the U.S., who isolated and cultured a live virus capable of binding to the human SARS receptor ACE2, indicating direct transmission potential from bats to humans. This finding challenges previous beliefs that civets were necessary intermediaries in the transmission of SARS to humans. The research underscores the importance of continued surveillance of bat populations to identify potentially pandemic viruses before they spill over to humans. The study was supported by various grants, including those from the NIH, NSF, and USAID's PREDICT program, which aims to identify pandemic threats in wildlife. EcoHealth Alliance emphasizes the need for public health measures to prevent such transmissions and highlights the ecological importance of bats. The organization continues to work on predicting and preventing pandemics through innovative research and global partnerships.

supporting_sources.title: Detection of Novel SARS-like and Other Coronaviruses in Bats from
supporting_sources.content: The study, "Detection of Novel SARS-like and Other Coronaviruses in Bats from Kenya," explores the presence and diversity of coronaviruses (CoVs) in bats from Kenya, a region previously underrepresented in such research. Given the role of bats as reservoirs for various infectious agents, including SARS-CoV, the study aimed to identify CoVs in bats from 17 locations in southern Kenya. Researchers conducted field surveys in July and August 2006, capturing bats and collecting blood, oral, and fecal samples. Using semi-nested reverse transcription–PCR assays, they screened 221 fecal swabs for CoV RNA, identifying 42 distinct CoV sequences. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that 23 sequences belonged to group 1 CoVs, while 16 were likely group 2, with some closely related to SARS-like CoVs. The study found that certain CoVs were specific to particular bat species, such as Miniopterus spp., while others were present across multiple species. This research highlights the significant CoV diversity in African bats, comparable to that in Asia, Europe, and North America, underscoring the potential for bats to introduce CoVs to other species globally. The findings emphasize the importance of understanding CoV diversity in bats to anticipate and mitigate public health threats similar to SARS. The study was supported by the Global Disease Detection program of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

supporting_sources.title: Two new SARS-like coronaviruses described in Russian horseshoe
supporting_sources.content: The article from News-Medical discusses the discovery of two new SARS-like coronaviruses in Russian horseshoe bats, conducted by a team of Russian scientists led by Dr. Sergey Alkhovsky from the Gamaleya Research Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology. Horseshoe bats are known reservoirs for zoonotic coronaviruses, which have previously led to significant human outbreaks, such as SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2. The study involved collecting 120 oral and 77 fecal samples from five species of horseshoe bats, followed by a phylogenetic analysis to identify viral residues. The researchers identified two novel coronaviruses, named BtCoV/Khosta-1/Rh/Russia/2020 and BtCoV/Khosta-2/Rh/Russia/2020, both belonging to the Betacoronavirus genus. Genetic analysis revealed that these viruses are similar to SARS-like coronaviruses found in Bulgarian and Kenyan bats but lack the ORF8 gene, distinguishing them from the SARS-CoV lineage. Khosta-1 showed high similarity to the Bulgarian 2008 CoV and SARS-CoV-2, while Khosta-2 was less similar to other known bat coronaviruses. The study highlights the genetic diversity and potential for new virus strains to emerge from bat populations, emphasizing the need for ongoing surveillance to assess their threat to humans. However, the findings are preliminary and not yet peer-reviewed, indicating that further research is necessary to understand the implications fully.

supporting_sources.title: Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) related coronavirus in bats
supporting_sources.content: The article published in "Animal Diseases" on April 23, 2021, by Rong Geng and Peng Zhou, explores the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)-related coronaviruses (SARSr-CoVs) found in bats, which are considered natural reservoirs for these viruses. The study provides a comprehensive review of the geographical distribution, genetic diversity, and cross-species transmission potential of bat SARSr-CoVs, emphasizing their role in past human coronavirus outbreaks such as SARS, MERS, and COVID-19. The authors highlight that bats harbor numerous SARSr-CoVs, which could potentially cause future outbreaks similar to SARS or COVID-19. The study utilized molecular and serological surveillance methods to identify SARSr-CoVs in various bat species, revealing a high genetic diversity with genome similarities ranging from 85% to 99% to human SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2. The research underscores the importance of monitoring these viruses due to their potential to cross species barriers, as evidenced by the use of the ACE2 receptor for cell entry, similar to SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2. The article also discusses the unique immune system of bats, which allows them to carry these viruses without succumbing to disease, and suggests that further surveillance and preventive measures, such as banning wildlife markets, are crucial to mitigate the risk of future pandemics.

supporting_sources.title: Discovery of a rich gene pool of bat SARS-related coronaviruses
supporting_sources.content: The article published in PLOS Pathogens details a comprehensive study conducted by researchers from the Wuhan Institute of Virology and other institutions, which explores the genetic diversity of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARSr-CoVs) in bats. Over a five-year period, the team conducted surveillance in a cave in Yunnan Province, China, inhabited by multiple species of horseshoe bats. They discovered 11 new SARSr-CoV strains, revealing a rich gene pool with high genetic diversity, particularly in the S gene, ORF3, and ORF8 regions. These strains showed significant genetic similarities to the SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV), especially in the hypervariable N-terminal domain (NTD) and receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the S1 gene. The study found evidence of frequent recombination events, suggesting that the direct progenitor of SARS-CoV may have originated from such events among these bat SARSr-CoVs. Importantly, some newly identified strains were capable of using human ACE2 as a receptor, indicating a potential for direct transmission to humans. This research provides new insights into the origin and evolution of SARS-CoV and underscores the importance of monitoring SARSr-CoVs to prepare for potential future outbreaks of SARS-like diseases. The study was supported by various funding bodies, including the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the USAID Emerging Pandemic Threats program.

supporting_sources.title: Detection of Group 1 Coronaviruses in Bats in North America - CDC
supporting_sources.content: The study investigates the presence of coronaviruses in bats in North America, prompted by the role of bats as reservoirs for SARS-like coronaviruses in Asia. Researchers collected and analyzed 79 samples from 57 bats across four locations in the Rocky Mountain region in August 2006, using reverse transcription-PCR to detect coronavirus RNA. They found coronavirus RNA in 6 of 28 fecal samples from two bat species, Eptesicus fuscus and Myotis occultus, with a prevalence of 17% and 50%, respectively. Sequence analysis of a 440-bp amplicon in gene 1b revealed that these coronaviruses belong to phylogenetic group 1, distinct from Asian bat coronaviruses. The study highlights the potential for bats to harbor coronaviruses that could pose a risk to humans and animals, emphasizing the need for further surveillance and characterization of bat coronaviruses in North America. The findings suggest that bats may be persistently infected carriers, shedding low levels of coronaviruses in feces, similar to patterns observed in Asian bats. The study underscores the importance of understanding the ecology and evolution of coronaviruses in wildlife, given the potential for future zoonotic transmission events.

supporting_sources.title: Identification of SARS-like coronaviruses in horseshoe bats
supporting_sources.content: The article published in the Archives of Virology details a study conducted in Slovenia, where researchers identified SARS-like coronaviruses in horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus hipposideros). Bats are known reservoirs for various zoonotic viruses, including coronaviruses linked to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). The study involved collecting fecal samples from 106 bats across seven species and 27 locations in Slovenia between May and October 2008. Using RT-PCR, coronaviruses were detected in 14 out of 36 horseshoe bat samples, indicating a 38.8% prevalence. Sequence analysis of a 405-nucleotide region of the RNA polymerase gene revealed that these coronaviruses are closely related, with 99.5–100% nucleotide identity, and belong to group 2 coronaviruses. The Slovenian strains showed 85% nucleotide identity and 95.6% amino acid identity with the SARS bat isolate Rp3/2004. The study highlights the potential risk of these bat coronaviruses as reservoirs for human infections, emphasizing the need for further molecular epidemiologic studies. The findings underscore the importance of understanding coronavirus reservoirs to predict and mitigate future disease outbreaks.

supporting_sources.title: Full-length genome sequences of two SARS-like coronaviruses in
supporting_sources.content: The article from the Journal of General Virology explores the genetic makeup of SARS-like coronaviruses found in horseshoe bats, which have been identified as natural reservoirs for these viruses. The study focuses on two specific group 2b coronaviruses (G2b-CoVs) isolated from the horseshoe bat species Rhinolophus ferrumequinum and Rhinolophus macrotis, named G2b-CoV Rf1 and G2b-CoV Rm1, respectively. Researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis of the complete genome sequences of these viruses, revealing that they share an identical genome organization and exhibit an overall genome sequence identity of 88–92% with each other and with SARS-CoV isolates from humans and palm civets. The study highlights significant genetic variability in regions encoding nsp3, ORF3a, spike protein, and ORF8 when comparing bat and human/civet G2b-CoV isolates. This genetic analysis underscores the existence of a diverse G2b-CoV population within the bat habitat, which has evolved from a common ancestor of SARS-CoV, providing crucial insights into the evolutionary dynamics of these viruses.

supporting_sources.title: Close relative of SARS virus found in Chinese bats | CIDRAP
supporting_sources.content: The article reports on a study published in Nature, where an international research team discovered two novel coronaviruses in Chinese horseshoe bats that are closely related to the SARS-CoV and capable of infecting human cells. This supports the hypothesis that the SARS virus originated in bats and suggests a potential direct transmission from bats to humans. The study involved a year-long genetic analysis of samples from a bat colony in Kunming, China, revealing at least seven strains of SARS-like viruses. Notably, two of these viruses were more closely related to SARS-CoV than previously identified viruses. The researchers successfully isolated a SARS-like virus from bat feces, which was found to use the same ACE2 receptor as SARS-CoV to infect human cells. Lab tests showed the virus could infect human alveolar epithelial cells, pig kidney cells, and bat kidney cells, but not other cell lines. Cross-neutralizing antibody tests with blood samples from SARS patients showed that most could neutralize the bat virus. The findings underscore the global public health threat posed by bat coronaviruses and highlight the need for continued surveillance and public health measures to mitigate disease transmission risks. The study was largely funded by US government agencies, including USAID's PREDICT project. Experts like Vincent Racaniello and Peter Daszak emphasized the importance of understanding the viruses in wildlife and the potential for direct bat-to-human transmission, while Michael Osterholm cautioned that the study does not definitively link infected bats to human infections, noting the complexity of transmission dynamics.

supporting_sources.title: Bat virus clues to origins of Sars - BBC News
supporting_sources.content: The article from BBC Radio Science Unit, authored by Keeren Flora, discusses a significant study that provides strong evidence supporting the theory that the Sars virus originated in bats. Researchers discovered two novel Sars-like coronaviruses in Chinese horseshoe bats, which are closely related to the human-infecting pathogen. These viruses bind to the ACE2 receptor in human cells, indicating a potential direct transmission from bats to humans, bypassing intermediate species like civets. Published in the journal Nature, the study highlights that these Sars-like coronaviruses share about 95% genetic similarity with the human Sars virus, suggesting their potential use in developing new vaccines and drugs. The Sars outbreak from 2002 to 2003, which caused over 8,000 cases and more than 770 deaths globally, along with the ongoing Mers-coronavirus endemic, underscores the threat posed by novel coronaviruses. Dr. Peter Daszak of the EcoHealth Alliance, a co-author of the study, emphasizes the rapid evolution of coronaviruses and their unusual ability to jump between species. The study suggests that close proximity between humans and bats, especially in Chinese wildlife markets and bat caves, facilitates virus transmission. Understanding the origins of such infectious diseases could enable scientists to preemptively tackle future outbreaks. Dr. Daszak estimates that discovering all mammalian viruses would cost about $1.5 billion, a worthwhile investment for developing vaccines and test kits to prevent initial infections.

supporting_sources.title: Chinese Horseshoe Bats Are Reservoirs of SARS - Vax-Before-Travel
supporting_sources.content: The study, as reported by CoronavirusToday, investigates the genetic sequences of hundreds of coronaviruses found in bats in China, aiming to understand their role as reservoirs for these viruses, particularly in relation to the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. Although the study, which was posted on May 31, 2020, and has not been peer-reviewed, does not pinpoint the exact origin of SARS-CoV-2, it highlights the genus Rhinolophus, or Chinese horseshoe bats, as significant in the evolution of coronaviruses. Researchers, including Dr. Peter Daszak, utilized a Bayesian statistical framework and sequence data from all known bat coronaviruses, including 630 novel sequences, to explore their macroevolution, cross-species transmission, and dispersal within China. The findings indicate that host-switching is more frequent and occurs across more distantly related host taxa in alpha-coronaviruses compared to beta-coronaviruses, with the latter being more constrained by phylogenetic distance. The study identifies Rhinolophidae and the genus Rhinolophus as common sites for inter-family and inter-genus switching, suggesting these as hotspots for coronavirus evolutionary diversity. This research provides a phylogenetic analysis that supports the likelihood of SARS-CoV-2 originating in Rhinolophus spp. bats, offering insights that could enhance proactive zoonotic disease surveillance. The authors have declared no competing interests, and the study was fact-checked by medical professionals, including Dr. Robert Carlson and Danielle Reiter, RN.

The article also touches on the use of cation exchange chromatography for characterizing biomolecules and the development of high-performance resins for biochromatography. Furthermore, it mentions upcoming events such as PITTCON 2025 and other international forums, providing a broad perspective on the current and future landscape of chromatography and related scientific fields.

supporting_sources.title: UPDATE ON HOW BATS RELATE TO THE OUTBREAK  - Secemu
supporting_sources.content: The article discusses the uncertain origins of the COVID-19 pandemic, which was declared a global health emergency by the World Health Organization in early 2020. It explores the potential links between bats and the outbreak, drawing parallels with previous coronavirus epidemics like SARS and MERS. The SARS outbreak in 2003 was traced back to civets, with bats identified as the natural reservoir, while MERS, emerging in 2012, was linked to dromedaries, with bats again suspected as the original source. For COVID-19, initial epidemiological studies suggested a wet market in China as the outbreak's origin, but no animal samples from the market have confirmed this. The closest known relative to SARS-CoV-2 is a bat-borne coronavirus, Bat CoV RATG13, found in horseshoe bats, and similar viruses have been identified in pangolins. However, the genetic distance between these viruses and SARS-CoV-2 suggests a common ancestor years ago, and no direct epidemiological link has been established. The article concludes that the source of the pandemic remains unknown, with no definitive evidence implicating bats or pangolins as the origin. It emphasizes that the pandemic's spread is due to human-to-human transmission and highlights the role of illegal wildlife trade in facilitating such outbreaks, urging international efforts to combat this issue to prevent future pandemics.

supporting_sources.title: Are bats to blame for the coronavirus crisis? - Illinois News Bureau
supporting_sources.content: The article by Diana Yates from the University of Illinois News Bureau explores the role of bats in the coronavirus crisis, addressing common misconceptions and the broader implications for human health and wildlife conservation. Tara Hohoff, a wildlife biologist with the Illinois Natural History Survey, clarifies that while bats can carry diseases like coronaviruses and rabies, they generally do not pose a direct threat to humans unless there is direct contact with their blood or saliva, which is rare in the U.S. The article highlights that bats are often misunderstood, with many people incorrectly associating them with rodents and assuming they frequently carry dangerous diseases. In reality, bats are a diverse group of mammals with varied diets and behaviors, and they typically avoid human interaction. The piece also discusses the role of wildlife markets in disease emergence, where unnatural proximity between different species can lead to spillover events, transferring pathogens to new hosts. Hohoff emphasizes the importance of respecting wildlife and maintaining their natural habitats to prevent such occurrences. Additionally, the article underscores the ecological benefits bats provide, such as pest control and pollination, which have significant economic and health implications. For instance, insectivorous bats contribute approximately $1 billion globally in pest suppression for crops like corn. The article concludes by advocating for the conservation of bats and further research into their unique immune systems, which could offer insights into disease resistance.

supporting_sources.title: New SARS-like virus discovered in Chinese horseshoe bats
supporting_sources.content: The article from UC Davis highlights a groundbreaking study published in Nature, where scientists, including a wildlife epidemiologist from the University of California, Davis, have isolated a live SARS-like coronavirus from Chinese horseshoe bats for the first time. This discovery is significant as it demonstrates the virus's ability to bind to the human SARS ACE2 receptor, indicating potential direct transmission from bats to humans without an intermediate host. The research, part of the USAID's Emerging Pandemic Threats program, involved genetic analyses of samples from a bat colony in Kunming, China, revealing at least seven strains of SARS-like coronaviruses. This finding challenges previous beliefs that civets were necessary intermediaries in the SARS transmission chain. The study underscores the importance of proactive surveillance of wildlife to identify pandemic-potential viruses before they spill over to humans. It also highlights the need for public health measures to mitigate transmission risks, especially as bats are a food source in parts of Asia. The research was supported by various international and national funding bodies, including the National Institutes of Health and the National Natural Science Foundation of China. The study's implications are vast, suggesting that protecting bat habitats and understanding virus diversity in wildlife are crucial steps in preventing future pandemics.

supporting_sources.title: NSF Award Search: Award # 2033973 - RAPID: Rapid Creation of a
supporting_sources.content: The National Science Foundation (NSF) awarded a RAPID grant to Florida State University to develop a comprehensive data product for the world's specimens of horseshoe bats and their relatives, which are known reservoirs for SARS-like coronaviruses, including SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. This project aimed to create georeferenced, vetted, and versioned data products by consolidating ancillary information linked to each bat specimen using the extended specimen model. The initiative addressed the challenge of vague or missing locality data in natural history collections, which hampers understanding the source, emergence, and distribution of SARS-CoV-2 and similar viruses. The project produced a research-ready dataset of nearly 90,000 bat specimens, enhancing geospatial data for 40% of the species and improving tools like GEOLocate for assigning geospatial coordinates. The dataset, shared on Zenodo, has been downloaded over 3,250 times as of mid-2022. The project also developed rapid response protocols for future crises and engaged early career professionals and trainees in using tools like Bionomia and Wikidata to improve data precision. The results were disseminated through publications, talks, and open-access platforms, contributing significantly to the global effort to understand and manage zoonotic diseases. This work was supported by funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act and aligns with NSF's mission to advance scientific knowledge and address broader societal impacts.

supporting_sources.title: Detection of a virus related to betacoronaviruses in Italian greater
supporting_sources.content: The article published by Cambridge University Press on May 18, 2010, investigates the presence of coronaviruses (CoVs) in Italian greater horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus ferrumequinum), a species known to be a reservoir for several CoVs, including those related to SARS-CoV. The study involved capturing 52 bats from various locations in Italy, collecting faecal samples and anal swabs, and testing for CoVs using reverse transcription–PCR (RT–PCR) targeting the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase gene. The results showed that 3.8% of the bats tested positive for CoVs, with two positive samples identified from different regions in Italy. Phylogenetic analysis of one sample revealed a close genetic relationship with SARS-related CoVs within the Betacoronavirus genus. The study highlights the low prevalence of CoVs in Italian bats compared to other regions, suggesting potential influences from climatic or geographical factors on virus transmission. The findings underscore the importance of further research to understand the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of CoVs in bats, their zoonotic potential, and the implications for public health and wildlife conservation.

supporting_sources.title: Coronaviruses in humans and animals: the role of bats in viral
supporting_sources.content: The article "Coronaviruses in humans and animals: the role of bats in viral evolution," published in Environmental Science and Pollution Research, explores the significant role bats play as natural reservoirs for coronaviruses, contributing to the emergence of viral diseases in humans and animals. The review highlights that coronaviruses, known for over 60 years, typically cause mild respiratory symptoms in humans but have led to severe epidemics since 2002, including SARS, MERS, and COVID-19. Bats are ideal hosts due to their immune system's tolerance to viruses, allowing them to harbor and shed viruses without showing symptoms. The study discusses the indirect transmission of coronaviruses through intermediate hosts like civet cats and camels and examines the lack of direct evidence linking bats to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, phylogenetic data, animal experiments, and computational models suggest bats' involvement in the virus's evolution. The article also reviews the genetic flexibility of coronaviruses, enabling rapid evolution and host adaptation, and emphasizes the need for regulating wildlife markets to prevent future outbreaks.

supporting_sources.title: SARS-related coronavirus - Wikipedia
supporting_sources.content: The article provides a comprehensive overview of the SARS-related coronavirus, a species within the Betacoronavirus genus, specifically the Sarbecovirus subgenus. This virus species includes numerous strains, two of which—SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2—have caused significant human respiratory disease outbreaks, namely the 2002-2004 SARS outbreak and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, respectively. Bats are identified as the primary reservoir for these viruses, with some strains also found in civets, which are believed to be ancestors of SARS-CoV-1. The virus is characterized by its enveloped, positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome, which is approximately 30 kilobases in length, making it one of the largest among RNA viruses. The genome encodes several structural proteins, including spike (S), envelope (E), membrane (M), and nucleocapsid (N) proteins, as well as accessory proteins with largely unknown functions. The virus enters host cells by binding to the ACE2 receptor, a process facilitated by the spike protein. The article also discusses the virus's replication strategy, which involves the formation of a replicase-transcriptase complex for RNA synthesis, and highlights the role of recombination in the virus's evolution. Phylogenetic analyses reveal that SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2, while sharing a common ancestor, evolved separately to infect humans. The article underscores the importance of understanding the virus's structure and life cycle to develop effective diagnostic tests, vaccines, and treatments, as emphasized by the World Health Organization's 2016 prediction of a potential epidemic, which materialized with the COVID-19 pandemic.

supporting_sources.title: Animals and COVID-19 - CDC
supporting_sources.content: The article discusses the relationship between animals and COVID-19, focusing on the transmission dynamics of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for the disease. It explains that coronaviruses are a large family of viruses, some of which can infect both humans and animals, though cross-species transmission is rare. SARS-CoV-2 likely originated in bats and can be transmitted from humans to animals, particularly during close contact. Documented cases of animal infections have occurred worldwide, often following exposure to infected humans. However, the risk of animals spreading the virus back to humans is considered low, with only a few instances reported, such as farmed mink in Europe and the U.S., white-tailed deer in Canada, pet hamsters in Hong Kong, and a cat in Thailand. The article highlights the potential for the virus to mutate in animals and possibly spill back to humans, necessitating further studies and surveillance. Mink farms have been a particular focus, with evidence of mink-to-human transmission in several countries. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), CDC, and other partners have developed guidelines to protect both human and animal health on these farms. The CDC has been actively involved in research and coordination efforts to better understand the virus's impact on animals and its transmission between species, emphasizing the need for ongoing studies to monitor potential variants and mutations.

supporting_sources.title: Study confirms cats can become infected with and may transmit
supporting_sources.content: The study published in the New England Journal of Medicine on May 13, 2020, led by Yoshihiro Kawaoka from the University of Wisconsin School of Veterinary Medicine, confirms that cats can be infected with SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, and potentially transmit it to other cats. In the laboratory, researchers infected three cats with the virus isolated from a human patient, and within three days, all cats tested positive. Subsequently, uninfected cats placed in the same cages also contracted the virus within six days, although none showed symptoms, and all eventually cleared the virus. The study highlights the potential for cats to contract the virus from humans or other infected cats, though there is no evidence of cats transmitting the virus to humans. The findings align with previous research from the Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences, which also indicated that cats and ferrets could be infected. Experts advise COVID-19 positive individuals to limit contact with pets and recommend keeping cats indoors to minimize exposure. The study, supported by the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development, underscores the importance of considering pets in COVID-19 safety protocols, although the risk of natural infection in cats remains low.

supporting_sources.title: Suspected Cat-to-Human Transmission of SARS-CoV-2, Thailand
supporting_sources.content: The article discusses a suspected case of cat-to-human transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in Thailand between July and September 2021. A veterinarian, referred to as patient A, contracted COVID-19 after a cat, owned by two COVID-19 positive individuals, sneezed on her during a veterinary examination. Genetic analysis supported the hypothesis of transmission from the cat to the veterinarian. The study was conducted during a period when the COVID-19 pandemic was transitioning from the Alpha to the Delta variant. The cat and its owners, patients B and C, traveled from Bangkok to Songkhla, where the cat was examined by patient A. Despite wearing protective gear, patient A was exposed to the virus through her eyes, as she did not wear a face shield or goggles. The genetic sequences of the virus from the cat, its owners, and patient A were identical, indicating a direct transmission link, distinct from other local cases. The study highlights the potential for zoonotic transmission of SARS-CoV-2 from cats to humans, although such occurrences are rare due to the short duration of viral shedding in cats. The findings emphasize the importance of eye protection for individuals in close contact with potentially infected animals.

supporting_sources.title: Human-to-animal COVID-19 spread not common
supporting_sources.content: The article by Malinda Larkin, published on April 29, 2020, addresses the concerns surrounding the transmission of COVID-19 from humans to animals, particularly pets. The context is set by initial reports of a Pomeranian in Hong Kong and two cats in New York testing positive for SARS-CoV-2, the virus causing COVID-19. Despite these cases, health organizations like the CDC, AVMA, and OIE emphasize that animals are not significant contributors to the spread of the virus, which is primarily driven by human-to-human contact. The article details various instances of animals testing positive, including a German Shepherd and a cat in Hong Kong, a cat in Belgium, and tigers at the Bronx Zoo, but notes that these cases are rare and often involve animals in close contact with infected humans. Dr. Jane Sykes from the University of California-Davis advises against overreacting to these cases, highlighting that routine testing of animals is not recommended. The article also references studies suggesting that while cats and ferrets might be susceptible to the virus in controlled settings, there is no real-world evidence of them transmitting it to humans. The AVMA and other organizations provide guidelines for handling pets in households with COVID-19 cases, stressing the importance of hygiene and minimal contact. The article concludes by noting the low prevalence of animal infections and the potential for false positives in testing, urging veterinarians to be cautious and informed.

supporting_sources.title: Cats may be able to contract SARS-CoV-2, but evidence is limited
supporting_sources.content: The article from Medical News Today discusses the potential for domestic animals, particularly cats, to contract SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. It highlights a preliminary study where researchers from the Harbin Veterinary Research Institute in China inoculated cats with high doses of the virus in a controlled setting. The study found that cats and ferrets are more susceptible to the virus compared to dogs, pigs, chickens, and ducks, where the virus replicates poorly. The researchers discovered viral RNA in the noses, mouths, and tonsils of the inoculated cats, and one cat exposed to infected cats also contracted the virus, indicating possible transmission between cats via respiratory droplets. However, the study's artificial conditions and small sample size limit its applicability to real-world scenarios. Despite some reports of pets testing positive for the virus, such as a Pomeranian and a German Shepherd in Hong Kong, and a cat in Belgium, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that domestic cats can transmit the virus to humans. Experts, including Prof. Linda Saif, emphasize the need for further research and caution against panic, as organizations like the World Small Animal Veterinary Association stress the lack of evidence for animal-to-human transmission. The article underscores the importance of focusing on reducing human-to-human transmission of COVID-19.

supporting_sources.title: Cats can infect each other with coronavirus, Chinese study finds
supporting_sources.content: The article reports on a study conducted by researchers at the Harbin Veterinary Research Institute in China, which found that cats are highly susceptible to Covid-19 and can transmit the virus to other cats through respiratory droplets. This study, which has not yet been peer-reviewed and was published on the preprint website bioRxiv, involved lab experiments where five cats were inoculated with the virus. Three of these cats were placed next to uninfected cats, resulting in one of the exposed cats becoming infected, indicating transmission. The findings were replicated in a second group of cats. While the study highlights the potential for cats to act as animal reservoirs for the virus, there is no direct evidence that cats can infect humans. The research suggests that surveillance of Sars-CoV-2 in cats could aid in controlling the pandemic. Experts, including Prof Eric Fèvre and Prof Jonathan Ball, emphasize that human-to-human transmission remains the primary driver of the pandemic, and cats are not considered a significant vector for spreading the virus to humans. They advise pet owners to practice good hygiene and limit close contact with pets if they are sick with Covid-19. The study also noted that ferrets are susceptible to the virus, while dogs, chickens, pigs, and ducks are unlikely to catch the infection.

supporting_sources.title: About the novel coronavirus, COVID-19
supporting_sources.content: The article provides comprehensive guidelines and resources related to COVID-19, focusing on the University of North Texas Health Science Center (HSC) community. It begins by explaining the background of coronaviruses, noting their commonality among animals and the emergence of COVID-19 in December 2019 in Wuhan, China. The virus primarily spreads through respiratory droplets, similar to the flu, and can be transmitted by asymptomatic individuals. To prevent the spread, the article advises staying home, wearing cloth face coverings, practicing social distancing, and maintaining hygiene through frequent handwashing and surface disinfection. It outlines the symptoms of COVID-19 and provides links to CDC resources for managing illness and when to seek medical attention. The article also details the mandatory face-covering policy effective June 25, 2020, at all UNT System locations, requiring masks in indoor public areas and outdoor spaces where distancing is not possible. Additionally, it offers resources for HSC employees and students, including counseling services and updates from the UNT System. The article emphasizes the importance of staying informed through reliable sources like the CDC and local health departments.

supporting_sources.content: The article from the American Lung Association provides a comprehensive overview of various resources and guidance related to lung health, tobacco cessation, air quality, and COVID-19's impact on pets. It encourages individuals affected by lung disease or those caring for them to join the Patient & Caregiver Network for support and education.
